name: runner
moduleDoc:
Test execution and orchestration engine for Probitas scenarios.

This package provides the {@linkcode ScenarioRunner} class that executes
scenario definitions built with `@probitas/builder`. It handles the complete
test lifecycle including resource initialization, setup/cleanup hooks,
step execution with retry logic, and result reporting.

## Links

- [GitHub Repository](https://github.com/jsr-probitas/probitas)
- [@probitas/probitas](https://jsr.io/@probitas/probitas) - Main package (recommended for most users)

## Related Packages

| Package | Description |
|---------|-------------|
| [@probitas/builder](https://jsr.io/@probitas/builder) | Build scenario definitions to execute |
| [@probitas/scenario](https://jsr.io/@probitas/scenario) | Core type definitions |
| [@probitas/reporter](https://jsr.io/@probitas/reporter) | Output formatters for results |
| [@probitas/cli](https://jsr.io/@probitas/cli) | CLI that uses this runner |

## Key Features

- **Concurrent execution**: Run multiple scenarios in parallel with configurable concurrency
- **Failure control**: Stop after N failures or continue through all tests
- **Resource lifecycle**: Automatic initialization and disposal of resources
- **Retry logic**: Built-in retry with linear/exponential backoff strategies
- **Reporter integration**: Pluggable reporters for custom output formatting
- **Abort support**: Cancel running tests via AbortSignal

## Core Exports

- {@linkcode ScenarioRunner} - Main class for executing scenarios
- {@linkcode Skip} - Exception class to skip scenarios conditionally
- {@linkcode Reporter} - Interface for observing test execution events
- {@linkcode RunOptions} - Configuration options for test runs
- {@linkcode RunSummary} - Aggregated results from a test run
- {@linkcode ScenarioResult} - Result from executing a single scenario
- {@linkcode StepResult} - Result from executing a single step

## Error Types

- {@linkcode TimeoutError} - Thrown when a step exceeds its timeout
- {@linkcode RetryExhaustedError} - Thrown when all retry attempts fail

jsDoc.doc:
Exception class for conditionally skipping scenario execution.

Throw `Skip` from any step, setup, or resource factory to skip the
entire scenario. Skipped scenarios are counted separately in the
summary and don't count as failures.

Common use cases:
- Feature flags or environment checks
- Prerequisites not met
- Platform-specific tests
- Temporary test disabling with clear reason
Create a Skip exception.

tags.name: reason
tags.doc:
- Optional explanation for why the scenario was skipped.
Displayed in test reports alongside the scenario name.

```ts
throw new Skip();                    // message: "Skipped", reason: undefined
throw new Skip("Not on Windows");    // message: "Not on Windows", reason: "Not on Windows"
```

jsDoc.doc:
Human-readable reason for skipping.

When provided, this reason is displayed in test reports.
If not provided, defaults to `undefined` (the error message
will still show "Skipped").

Main scenario runner

Executes scenarios with full lifecycle management, filtering, and reporting.
Run scenarios and return execution summary

tags.name: scenarios
tags.doc: Scenarios to execute

tags.name: options
tags.doc: Execution options (reporter, concurrency, failure handling)
Promise resolving to execution summary

jsDoc.doc:
Runtime context for scenario execution.

Provides access to scenario metadata, accumulated results, shared storage,
and resources during scenario execution. This is the "live" counterpart
to the static {@linkcode ScenarioDefinition}.

tags.name: Resources
tags.doc: - Record of available resource types

jsDoc.doc: Human-readable scenario name
Scenario configuration options
Array of all step results so far
Shared key-value storage for cross-step communication
Abort signal (fires on timeout or manual cancellation)
Named resources registered with `.resource()`

Result from executing a single step.

Contains the step's execution status, timing, and either the return
value (on success) or error (on failure). Used by reporters to display
step-level results.
Step metadata (serializable, without function)
Execution outcome: "passed" or "failed"
Execution time in milliseconds
Return value from step function (only if status is "passed")
Error that caused failure (only if status is "failed")

Result from executing a complete scenario.

Contains the overall scenario status, timing, all step results,
and any error or skip reason. Passed to reporters and included
in the final {@linkcode RunSummary}.
Scenario metadata (serializable, without functions)
Overall execution outcome
Total execution time in milliseconds (including setup/teardown)
Results from each executed step
Error if failed during resource/setup/teardown (not step errors)
Reason for skipping (only if status is "skipped")

Summary of all scenario executions in a test run.

Provides aggregate statistics and detailed results for the entire run.
Passed to {@linkcode Reporter.onRunEnd} after all scenarios complete.
Total number of scenarios in the run
Number of scenarios that passed
Number of scenarios that failed
Number of scenarios that were skipped
Total execution time in milliseconds
Detailed result for each scenario

Filter configuration for selecting scenarios to run.

Allows filtering scenarios by tags and/or name pattern.
Both conditions must match if both are specified (AND logic).
Tags that scenarios must have (all must match)
Pattern to match against scenario name

Reporter interface for observing and reporting test execution.

Implement this interface to create custom reporters. All methods are
optional - implement only the hooks you need. Methods can be sync or async.

Built-in reporters:
- {@linkcode ListReporter} - Detailed hierarchical output
- {@linkcode DotReporter} - Compact dot notation
- {@linkcode TAPReporter} - TAP format for CI integration
- {@linkcode JSONReporter} - Machine-readable JSON
Called when the test run starts, before any scenarios execute.

jsDoc.doc: Called when scenario completes
Called when test run completes

Configuration options for the scenario runner.

Controls execution behavior including concurrency, failure handling,
and reporting.
Reporter instance for execution events

Maximum number of scenarios to run in parallel.

- `undefined` or `0`: Unlimited (all scenarios run in parallel)
- `1`: Sequential execution (one at a time)
- `n`: Run up to n scenarios concurrently

Maximum number of failures before stopping the run.

- `undefined`: Continue all scenarios regardless of failures
- `1`: Fail-fast (stop immediately on first failure)
- `n`: Stop after n failures

Abort signal for external cancellation.

When aborted, running scenarios complete but no new ones start.

Discriminated union representing an entry in a scenario.

A scenario consists of an ordered sequence of entries, where each entry
is either a step, resource, or setup. The `kind` field serves as the
discriminant for type narrowing.

Serializable entry metadata for JSON output and tooling.

Same discriminated union structure as {@linkcode Entry}, but with
functions omitted for serialization.

Immutable definition of a named resource.

Resource definitions contain everything needed to create and identify
a resource: its name, factory function, and source location.

tags.doc: - Type of the previous step's result

tags.doc: - Tuple type of accumulated results

tags.doc: - Previously registered resources available to this factory

jsDoc.doc: Unique resource name (used as key in `ctx.resources`)
Factory function that creates the resource
Source location where the resource was defined

Function signature for resource factory functions.

Resource factories create named dependencies that are:
- Initialized before any steps run
- Available to all steps via `ctx.resources[name]`
- Automatically disposed after the scenario (if Disposable)

tags.name: T
tags.doc: - Type of resource to create

tags.name: Previous
tags.doc: - Type of the previous step's result

tags.name: Results
tags.doc: - Tuple type of accumulated results

tags.name: Resources
tags.doc: - Previously registered resources available to this factory

jsDoc.doc:
Serializable resource metadata (without the factory function).

Contains the resource name and source location.

Complete, immutable definition of a scenario.

This is the core type produced by the builder and consumed by the runner.
It contains everything needed to execute a scenario: its name, options,
and ordered sequence of entries (steps, resources, setups).

tags.value:
@remarks
Scenario definitions are:
- **Immutable**: The entries array is frozen after creation
- **Self-contained**: All options have defaults applied
- **Portable**: Can be serialized (minus functions) for tooling

jsDoc.doc: Human-readable scenario name (displayed in reports and CLI)
Scenario configuration with all defaults applied
Ordered sequence of entries (resources → setups → steps)
Source location where the scenario was defined

Serializable scenario metadata (without executable functions).

Used by the JSON reporter and tooling to output scenario information
without including non-serializable function references.
Scenario name
Scenario configuration options
Entry metadata (functions omitted for serialization)
Source location where the scenario was defined

Configuration options for scenario execution.

Defines metadata and default behavior for an entire scenario.

tags.doc: {@linkcode StepOptions} for step-level configuration

jsDoc.doc:
Tags for filtering and organizing scenarios.

Tags can be used with the CLI to run specific subsets:
```bash
probitas run -s "tag:api"           # Run scenarios tagged "api"
probitas run -s "tag:api,tag:fast"  # Run scenarios with both tags
probitas run -s "!tag:slow"         # Exclude slow scenarios
```

Default options applied to all steps in this scenario.

Individual steps can override these defaults by specifying
their own options in the `.step()` call.

Cleanup handler returned by setup functions.

Setup functions can return various cleanup mechanisms that are automatically
invoked after the scenario completes (regardless of success or failure).

Supported cleanup patterns:
- `void` / `undefined`: No cleanup needed
- `() => void`: Synchronous cleanup function
- `() => Promise<void>`: Async cleanup function
- `Disposable`: Object with `[Symbol.dispose]()` method
- `AsyncDisposable`: Object with `[Symbol.asyncDispose]()` method

Immutable definition of a setup hook.

Setup definitions contain the setup function and its source location.
Unlike steps, setups don't have names or configurable options.

tags.name: Previous
tags.doc: - Type of the previous step's result

tags.name: Results
tags.doc: - Tuple type of accumulated results

tags.name: Resources
tags.doc: - Record of available resources

jsDoc.doc: Setup function to execute (may return cleanup handler)
Source location where the setup was defined

Function signature for setup hooks.

Setup functions run before steps and can return a cleanup handler
that executes after the scenario completes (success or failure).

tags.name: Previous
tags.doc: - Type of the previous step's result

tags.name: Results
tags.doc: - Tuple type of accumulated results

tags.name: Resources
tags.doc: - Record of available resources
{@linkcode SetupCleanup} for supported cleanup return types

jsDoc.doc:
Serializable setup metadata (without the function).

Contains only the source location since setups have no name or options.

Source location in a file for error reporting and debugging.

Captured automatically when defining scenarios, steps, and setups.
Used by reporters to show meaningful stack traces.
Absolute file path where the element was defined
Line number in the file (1-indexed)

Execution context provided to steps, resources, and setup hooks.

The context provides access to:
- Previous step results with full type inference
- All accumulated results as a typed tuple
- Named resources registered with `.resource()`
- Shared storage for cross-step communication
- Abort signal for timeout and cancellation handling

tags.name: Previous
tags.doc: - Type of the previous step's return value

tags.name: Results
tags.doc: - Tuple type of all accumulated results from previous steps

tags.name: Resources
tags.doc: - Record type mapping resource names to their types

jsDoc.doc:
Current step index (0-based).

Useful for conditional logic based on position in the scenario.

Result from the previous step.

Fully typed based on what the previous step returned.
For the first step, this is `unknown`.

All accumulated results as a typed tuple.

Allows accessing any previous result by index:
```ts
ctx.results[0]  // First step's result
ctx.results[1]  // Second step's result
```

Shared key-value storage for cross-step communication.

Use this for data that doesn't fit the step result pattern,
such as metadata or configuration set during setup.

Abort signal that fires on timeout or manual cancellation.

Pass this to fetch() or other APIs that support AbortSignal
for proper timeout handling.

Named resources registered with `.resource()`.

Resources are typed based on their registration:
```ts
.resource("db", () => createDbConnection())
.step((ctx) => ctx.resources.db.query(...))
```

Immutable definition of a scenario step.

Contains all information needed to execute a single step:
the step function, its options, and debugging metadata.

tags.name: T
tags.doc: - Type of this step's return value

tags.name: Previous
tags.doc: - Type of the previous step's result

tags.name: Results
tags.doc: - Tuple type of accumulated results

tags.name: Resources
tags.doc: - Record of available resources

jsDoc.doc: Human-readable step name (displayed in reports)
Step function to execute
Step execution options (timeout, retry) with defaults applied
Source location where the step was defined (for error messages)

Function signature for step execution.

A step function receives the execution context and returns a value
(sync or async) that becomes available to subsequent steps.

tags.name: T
tags.doc: - Type of this step's return value

tags.name: Previous
tags.doc: - Type of the previous step's result (from `ctx.previous`)

tags.name: Results
tags.doc: - Tuple type of all accumulated results

tags.name: Resources
tags.doc: - Record of available resources

jsDoc.doc:
Serializable step metadata (without the function).

Used for JSON output, tooling, and inspection without executing code.

Configuration options for individual step execution.

Controls timeout and retry behavior for a step. These options can be set at:
1. Step level (highest priority)
2. Scenario level (applies to all steps in scenario)
3. Default values (30s timeout, no retry)

Maximum execution time in milliseconds.

If the step takes longer, a {@linkcode TimeoutError} is thrown.
Default: 30000 (30 seconds)
Retry configuration for handling transient failures

Maximum number of execution attempts.

- `1` = No retry (fail immediately on error)
- `2` = One retry (2 total attempts)
- `n` = n-1 retries (n total attempts)

Default: 1 (no retry)

Backoff strategy for delay between retry attempts.

- `"linear"`: Fixed 1 second delay between attempts
- `"exponential"`: Doubles delay each attempt (1s, 2s, 4s, 8s...)

Default: "linear"

Error that occurs during scenario execution (setup, teardown, or resource handling).

Wraps errors that happen outside of step execution, such as:
- Resource initialization failures
- Setup function errors
- Cleanup/teardown errors
Create a scenario error.

tags.name: message
tags.doc: - Descriptive error message

tags.name: scenario
tags.doc: - The scenario definition where the error occurred

tags.name: cause
tags.doc: - The underlying error that caused this error

jsDoc.doc:
Error that occurs during step execution.

Wraps errors thrown by step functions, including retry information.
Provides access to the step definition for error reporting.
Create a step error.

tags.name: message
tags.doc: - Descriptive error message

tags.name: step
tags.doc: - The step definition that failed

tags.name: attempt
tags.doc: - Which attempt failed (1-based, accounts for retries)

tags.name: cause
tags.doc: - The original error thrown by the step function

jsDoc.doc:
Error that occurs when a step exceeds its configured timeout.

Thrown when a step's execution time exceeds its `timeout` option.
The timeout value is available for error messages and retry logic.
Create a timeout error.

tags.name: message
tags.doc: - Descriptive error message

tags.name: timeout
tags.doc: - The timeout value in milliseconds that was exceeded
